snippet: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.
abstract: Study in New England Journal of Medicine examines results of program in St Louis that counseled teenage girls and provided them with free contraception, including long-acting methods like intrauterine devices and hormonal implants; relates that girls who participated in program had less than a quarter of the annual pregnancy, birth and abortion rates of teenage girls nationally.
lead_paragraph: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.

headline.main: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives
headline.print_headline: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives
